  2. Operation

    User

    1. Add a user: adduser

          sudo adduser username
    # when creating a new user, a new group that has the same name as the user will also be created.
    # and the user belongs to this group.

      * "useradd" command creates a user without home directory, password ....

    2. Add a user to the sudo group: usermod -aG

          sudo usermod -aG sudo username

    3. Delete a user: userdel -r

          sudo userdel -r username
    # -r means removing the user's home directory and mail spool.

    4. Reset user password

          passwd username 
    # no sudo permission is required to reset self password

    Group

    1. show the user's groups: groups

          groups [username] # if username is empty, then it checks the current user.
    # print all the groups that the user belongs to
    # include a user's name group.
    # It can check if you are in the sudo group

    2. When a user creates a file, the file's owner is the creator, file's group is the group that has the same name as the user.

      Usually, the username group just has the user itself, we can add other users to this group to give them group permission.
